Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Size-effect driven nanoparticle ferromagnetism
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical abstract:
Magnetic size effects are related to the dependence of the magnetic properties on the dimensions of the magnetic material being studied. Noble metals like gold have not traditionally been considered as magnetic materials because of the lack of permanent magnetism in their bulk forms. However, recent research has shown that nanomaterials may have strikingly different physical properties and indeed noble metals may become magnetic below some critical feature size. The current research project is an integrated research and education program to understand the size dependence of the magnetic properties of noble metals. This is the first detailed study on the size and shape dependence of the magnetic properties of noble metal nanoparticles. A variety of techniques are being used to determine the composition, size and size distribution and magnetic properties of the noble metal nanoparticles. Students in kindergarten through high school and undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds are involved in this research via a research-based mentoring program.

Technical abstract:
The research objective of this proposal is to test the hypothesis that reducing the dimensions of certain normally diamagnetic metals to the nanoscale can result in ferromagnetism. Reports of ferromagnetism in noble metal nanoparticles like gold are considered controversial because the findings contradict well-established physics. Laser-processing techniques are being used to synthesize nanoparticle samples of noble metals like gold, silver and palladium of desired sizes in oxide thin films. Deposition of the nanoparticles in nonmagnetic oxide thin films simultaneously provides synthesis, suppressed agglomeration, and in-situ passivation of the nanoparticles by the oxide thin films (magnesia, alumina, etc.). Detailed atomic-level structural characterization and high-resolution physical property measurements along with element specific magnetization studies are being used to thoroughly characterize the samples. The magnetic studies include static and dynamic measurements and ferromagnetic and electron paramagnetic resonance studies of the nanoparticles. Understanding the size-dependent behavior of these materials will elucidate the origin of the ferromagnetism in noble and near-noble nanoparticles. The project supports 2 graduate students and involves several undergraduate students. The educational objectives of this proposal are to: mentor a diverse group of high achieving students to STEM careers and contribute to K-12 STEM recruitment efforts. Undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds will be involved in our research-based mentoring program: Success Through Enthusiasm and Awareness of Materials Engineering Research (Project STEAMER). All of the educational and outreach activities will be assessed to monitor the efficacy of the programming and to contribute to the literature on STEM-based education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ferromagnetism (the property of a material being a permanent magnet) has been thought to be limited to only a few materials like iron, cobalt, and some other compounds. However, recently researchers discovered that small metal nanoparticles like gold behave as ferromagnets under certain conditions.

The origin of this intriguing finding was not well understood. Some researchers suggested that the gold particles become ferromagnetic because of a polymer coating that is applied during the synthesis of the particles. This polymer coating contains thiol groups, which result in the sulfur in the polymer bonding with gold metal atoms in the particle. The gold sulfur bonding is important as it allows for a solution of gold particles in a liquid to remain disperse. The researchers suggested that this bonding could be a means by which magnetism is induced in small gold particles. Others suggested that magnetism in gold particles was a natural feature of the material as the dimensions of the material were reduced to less than 100 nanometers.

The challenge in understanding whether magnetism in gold particles naturally occurs or is induced is complicated by the difficult of producing small gold particles that remain disperse. Aggregation of the particles results in a much larger effective particle size, which could shield the impact of the small size on the magnetic properties of gold.

We developed an experimental approach to fabricate gold nanoparticles inside of non-magnetic films. This approach allows us to use magnetic measurements to determine the magnetic properties of gold as the dimensions are reduced without the interference of the organic capping layers that might complicate investigation of the origin of magnetic signals from the material.

Our investigation definitely proves that gold nanoparticles are ferromagnetic for gold particles with diameters less than 10 nanometers. Magnetic impurities were ruled out as being the source of the magnetic signal by analyzing the composition of the material. The non-gold components that are potentially magnetic were present in too small amounts to contribute to the magnetic signals that were observed.

Funding from this project was also used to train one doctoral student, provide materials and supplies for another doctoral student project, and to support three undergraduate researchers, and outreach activities at local elementary schools. The outreach activities were centered around our research accomplishments and designed to motivate students to pursue STEM-based careers, particularly those in materials science and engineering.
